solution.text:
Given numbers are :
_{{((16*j)+7)*i}}_ and _{{((7*j)+3)*i}}_
According to Euclid's division lemma:
c = dq + r
Step 1 : Since _{{((16*j)+7)*i}}_ > _{{((7*j)+3)*i}}_,
We apply the division lemma to _{{((16*j)+7)*i}}_ and _{{((7*j)+3)*i}}_
to get:
_{{((16*j)+7)*i}}_ = \(_{{((7*j)+3)*i}}_\times 2\) + _{{((2*j)+1)*i}}_
Step 2 : Since the remainder \(_{{((2*j)+1)*i}}_\neq 0\)
We apply the division lemma to :
_{{((7*j)+3)*i}}_ and _{{((2*j)+1)*i}}_
_{{((7*j)+3)*i}}_ = \(_{{((2*j)+1)*i}}_\times 3\) + _{{j*i}}_
Step 3 : Applying lemma until remainder becomes zero.
We consider the new divisor _{{((2*j)+1)*i}}_ and the new remainder _{{j*i}}_, and apply the division lemma to get:
_{{((2*j)+1)*i}}_ = \(_{{j*i}}_\times 2\) + _{i}_
Again,
We consider the new divisor _{{j*i}}_ and the new remainder _{i}_, and apply the division lemma to get:
_{{j*i}}_ = \(_{i}_\times _{j}_\) + 0
The remainder has now become zero, so our procedure stops.
Since the divisor at this stage is _{i}_, the HCF of _{{163*i}}_ and _{{21*i}}_ is _{i}_

content.text: Find the HCF of _{{((16*j)+7)*i}}_ and _{{((7*j)+3)*i}}_ using Euclid's division algorithm.
